facts.text: The appellant married the respondent according to Hindu rites on April 20, 1955.
After marriage, parties lived together for about three years at Delhi, Alwar, Bombay and Europe.
According to appellant, marriage was not consummated during this period.

Appellant filed petition before District Judge, Delhi on March 15, 1960 under s.12 Hindu Marriage Act praying for annulment on ground that respondent was impotent at time of marriage and continued to be so, causing non-consummation due to her invincible and persistent repugnance.
Respondent denied repugnance, stated she was always ready for consummation, but appellant suffered from physical disability or impotency and never attempted it.
Respondent alleged appellant was physically and sexually impotent, unable to perform normal sexual functions, and never expressed willingness to consummate despite living together and sharing bed.

District Judge held appellant failed to prove respondent impotent (Issue 1 against appellant), and facts showed appellant unable to consummate due to physical or psychological cause (Issue 2). Petition dismissed.

Punjab High Court (Circuit Bench Delhi) on appeal: Differed on Issue 2 (not proved appellant impotent), but held appellant failed to prove respondent impotent or non-consummation due to her impotency or repugnance. Confirmed dismissal.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave heard, conclusion indicated April 28, 1969 to dismiss without costs, reasons later.
Both parties examined by doctors; oral evidence and reports on record.

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondent was impotent at the time of the marriage and continued to be so until the institution of the proceedings (s.12(1)(a) Hindu Marriage Act)?
Whether the petitioner (appellant) was impotent and consequently unable to perform normal sexual function with the respondent?
Whether non-consummation was due to invincible repugnance on part of respondent, making consummation practically impossible?

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent impotent at time of marriage and continued so, causing non-consummation despite frequent attempts by petitioner.
Even if not impotent, invincible repugnance by respondent made consummation practically impossible.
Lower courts ignored or misconstrued evidence; respondent's evidence of willingness not believable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Earnest John White v. Kathleen Olive White

respondent_arguments.text: No repugnance; always ready and willing for consummation during three years cohabitation including abroad; appellant impotent and never attempted.
Not impotent at marriage or institution of proceedings; appellant physically and emotionally unable.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant failed to prove respondent impotent at marriage and continuing; both lower courts concurrently found against appellant on evidence, including medical reports.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below neither ignored nor misconstrued evidence.

court_reasoning.text: High Court differed on appellant's impotency but held non-consummation not due to respondent's impotency or repugnance; disbelieved appellant's attempts and found lack of proper approach by appellant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allegation of invincible repugnance not proved.

court_reasoning.text: Earnest John White inapplicable as no ignoring/misconstruing of evidence.
G.v.G (1924) inapplicable as appellant's evidence on attempts/repugnance disbelieved.
Other G.v.G distinguishable; here both not normal or unable quoad hunc; position entirely different.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No basis to annul without fault attribution.

holdings.text: Appellant failed to establish respondent impotent under s.12(1)(a); no invincible repugnance proved.
No interference with concurrent findings of lower courts on facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Earnest John White v. Kathleen Olive White
precedents_cited.relevance: Interference on facts only if evidence ignored/misconstrued; not applicable here.
Nullity granted for wife's invincible repugnance despite potency; inapplicable as repugnance/attempts disbelieved.
Annulment where consummation impossible quoad hunc despite both normal; position here different.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Marriage Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground for nullity: respondent impotent at marriage and continuing, making consummation practically impossible.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed affirming High Court and District Judge; no interference with findings that respondent not impotent and no repugnance proved; marriage not annulled.
outcome.costs: Without any order as to costs

key_quotes.text: "A party is impotent if his or her mental or physical condition makes consummation of the marriage a practical impossibility."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We are satisfied that the Courts below... have neither ignored nor misconstrued important pieces of evidence."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The position in the case before us is entirely different."
key_quotes.speaker: court
